revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Phantom of the Opera | image = Phantom of the Opera (1943 film).jpg | caption = Theatrical re-release poster | director = [[Arthur Lubin]] | producer = [[George Waggner]] | screenplay = {{plain list| * [[Samuel Hoffenstein]] * [[Eric Taylor (screenwriter)|Eric Taylor]] }} | story = [[Hans Jacoby|John Jacoby]] | based on = {{Based on|''[[The Phantom of the Opera]]''|[[Gaston Leroux]]}} | starring = {{plain list| * [[Claude Rains]] * [[Nelson Eddy]] * [[Susanna Foster]] * [[Edgar Barrier]] }} | music = [[Edward Ward (composer)|Edward Ward]] | cinematography = {{plain list| * [[W. Howard Greene]] * [[Hal Mohr]] }} | editing = Russell F. Schoengarth | studio = [[Universal Pictures]] | distributor = Universal Pictures | released = {{film date|1943|8|12|}} | runtime = 92 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $1.75 millionMichael Brunas, John Brunas & Tom Weaver, ''Universal Horrors: The Studios Classic Films, 1931-46'', McFarland, 1990 p361 |gross = {{plain list| * $1.6 million
{{small|(US rentals)}}[https://archive.org/stream/variety153-1944-01#page/n51/mode/2up "Top Grossers of the Season", ''Variety'', 5 January 1944 p 54] * 2,316,416 admissions
{{small|(France, 1945)}}[http://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?depth=1&hl=en&prev=search&rurl=translate.google.com.au&sl=fr&u=http://www.boxofficestory.com/france-1945-c22731925&usg=ALkJrhiPuUc4vZGBcb7OUARBcpu2dF_c5A French box office in 1945] at Box office story }} }} '''''Phantom of the Opera''''' is a 1943 American [[horror film]] directed by [[Arthur Lubin]], loosely based on [[Gaston Leroux]]'s 1910 novel ''[[The Phantom of the Opera]]'' and its [[The Phantom of the Opera (1925 film)|1925 film adaptation]] starring [[Lon Chaney]]. Produced and distributed by [[Universal Pictures]], the film stars [[Nelson Eddy]], [[Susanna Foster]] and [[Claude Rains]], and was filmed in [[Technicolor]]. The original music score was composed by [[Edward Ward (composer)|Edward Ward]]. The auditorium set, a replica of the [[Palais Garnier|Opéra Garnier]] interior, created for the previous iteration was reused. Other than the sets, this remake had little in common with the earlier film. The original storyline was completely revised and there was no attempt to film the [[Masquerade ball|masked ball]] sequence, although the famous falling of the chandelier was re-enacted on an epic scale, using elaborate camera set-ups. It is also the only Universal horror film to win an [[Academy Awards|Oscar]], for [[Academy Award for Best Production Design|Art Direction]] and [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography|Cinematography]]. ==Plot== [[Violin]]ist Erique Claudin is dismissed from the [[Palais Garnier|Paris Opera House]] after revealing that he is losing the use of the fingers of his left hand. Unbeknownst to the conductor, who assumes Claudin is able to support himself, the musician has used all his money to help anonymously fund the voice lessons for Christine Dubois, a young soprano with whom he has fallen in love. In a desperate attempt to earn money, Claudin submits a [[Piano concerto|piano concerto]] he has written for publication. After submitting it and not hearing a response, he becomes worried and returns to the publishers, Pleyel & Desjardins, to ask about it. No one there knows what happened to it, and do not seem to care. Claudin persists, but Maurice Pleyel rudely tells him to leave and goes back to the [[etching]]s he was working on. Finally giving up, Claudin stands there for a moment and hangs his head sadly. Someone begins to play music in the next room, and he looks up in shock when he hears it. It is his concerto that is merely being endorsed and praised by [[Franz Liszt]]. Convinced that Pleyel is trying to steal his concerto, Claudin leaps up and begins to strangle him. Just as he tosses the body of Pleyel to the floor, Georgette, the publisher's assistant, throws etching acid at Claudin. Screaming and wailing in agony, Claudin dashes out the door clutching his face. Now being hunted down by the police for murder, he flees to the sewers of the Opera. Claudin steals a prop [[mask]] from the costume department to cover his now-disfigured face. Meanwhile, Inspector Raoul Dubert ([[Edgar Barrier]]) wants Christine to quit the Opera and marry him. But famed opera baritone Anatole Garron ([[Nelson Eddy]]) hopes to win Christine's heart. Christine considers them both good friends but doesn't openly express if she loves them. During a performance of the opera ''Amore et Gloire'', Claudin drugs a glass of wine which Biancarolli drinks and makes her collapse and unable to perform. The director puts Christine in her place and she dazzles both the audience and everyone else with her singing. However Mme. Biancarolli, who suspects that Garron and Christine are responsible for drugging her, orders Raoul to arrest them but he says he can't because there is no evidence to prove her statement true. So Biancarolli sets a condition that she will forget the whole affair only if Christine's performance is not mentioned in the papers. Her conditions are reluctantly accepted, much to Christine and Anatole's dismay. The next night Claudin enters Biancarolli's dressing room and kills her and her maid. The opera is subsequently closed. After some time, the opera's owners receive a note demanding that Christine replace Biancarolli. To catch Claudin, Raoul comes up with a plan: not let Christine sing during a performance of the (fictive) Russian opera ''Le prince masqué du Caucase'' (“The Masked Prince of the Caucasus”) so as to lure Claudin out into the open, while Garron plans to have Liszt play the concerto after the performance. But Claudin strangles one of Dubert's men and heads to the domed ceiling of the auditorium. He then brings down the large chandelier on the audience causing chaos. As the audience and the crew flee, Claudin takes Christine down underground. He tells Christine that he loves her and that she will now sing all she wants, but only for him. But Christine doesn't recognize Claudin and is afraid of him. Raoul, Anatole and the police begin pursuing them underground. Just as Claudin and Christine arrive in his lair they hear Liszt and the orchestra playing Claudin's concerto. Claudin plays along with it on his piano. Christine watches, realizing the concerto was written around the melody of a lullaby she had known since childhood. Raoul and Anatole hear Claudin playing and follow the sound. Overjoyed, Claudin urges Christine to sing, which she does. While Claudin is distracted by the music, Christine sneaks up and pulls off his mask and sees his burnt disfigured face caused by the acid. At that same moment, Raoul and Anatole break in. Claudin grabs a sword to fight them with. Raoul fires his gun at Claudin, but Anatole knocks Raoul's arm and the shot hits the ceiling causing a cave in. Anatole and Raoul escape with Christine but Claudin gets crushed to death by the falling rocks. Once they're safe, Anatole tells Christine that she and Claudin had come from the same town district, which explains why they both knew the lullaby. She responds by saying while Claudin had seemed a bit like a stranger to her she had somehow "always felt drawn to him" (an earlier version of the script had Claudin be Christine's biological father, who abandoned her and her mother—this explains his devotion and knowledge of the lullaby). Anatole finishes by saying that Claudin's madness will be forgotten, but his concerto will live on. Later, Anatole and Raoul demand that Christine finally chooses between the two men. She surprises them by choosing to marry neither one of them and pursue her singing career, because she now understands how much Claudin loved her and how much he was devoted to her singing career. She leaves the room and joins her adoring fans outside. The film ends with Anatole and Raoul going off to commiserate together. ==Cast== [[File:Phantom of the Opera (1943) trailer 1.jpg|thumb|267px|Susanna Foster and [[Nelson Eddy]]]] {{div col|colwidth=26em}} *[[Claude Rains]] as [[Erik (The Phantom of the Opera)|Erique Claudin/The Phantom of the Opera]]. Former violinist of the Opera House who becomes The Phantom. Secretly devoted to Christine. *[[Nelson Eddy]] as Anatole Garron. A baritone of the Opera who loves Christine and helps her with her career. *[[Susanna Foster]] as [[Christine Daaé|Christine DuBois]]. A young soprano of the Opera House. She is unaware that Erique Claudin loves her and was the one who funded all her singing lessons. *[[Edgar Barrier]] as [[Viscount Raoul de Chagny|Raoul Dubert]]. A policeman who wants Christine to quit the Opera and marry him. *Jane Farrar as [[Carlotta (The Phantom of the Opera)|Biancarolli]]. An arrogant, spoiled diva who dislikes being upstaged. *[[J. Edward Bromberg]] as Amiot *[[Fritz Feld]] as Lecours *[[Frank Puglia]] as Villeneuve *[[Fritz Leiber (actor)|Fritz Leiber]] as [[Franz Liszt]] *[[Steven Geray]] as Vercheres *[[Miles Mander]] as Maurice Pleyel *Hans Herbert as Marcel *[[Hume Cronyn]] as Gerard *[[Hank Mann]] as Stagehand (uncredited) {{div col end}} ==Development== Universal first announced a remake of ''The Phantom of the Opera'' in 1935. This version would have been set in contemporary Paris, and would have portrayed the Phantom as a psychologically wounded [[World War I]] veteran who was physically unharmed, but imagined that he was disfigured. The screenplay lingered in development until 1941, when [[Henry Koster]] was brought on board to direct. Koster discarded the previous screenplay, and envisioned a new version of the story in which the Phantom was Christine's father. Producer George Waggner ultimately fired Koster from the project and replaced him with Arthur Lubin."The Opera Ghost: A Phantom Unmasked". [Special Feature on DVD release of ''Phantom of the Opera'']. Universal Studios, 2000. ==Production== [[Cesar Romero]], [[Boris Karloff]], [[Feodor Chaliapin]], [[Charles Laughton]] and [[Broderick Crawford]] were all considered for the role of the Phantom at various points during production, before the role was given to Rains. Koster's subplot about the Phantom being Christine's father was jettisoned because it gave the romantic elements of their relationship [[incest]]uous overtones.Scott McQueen, audio-commentary on ''Phantom of the Opera'' DVD (Universal) During the same year that the film was released, ''Phantom of the Opera'' was adapted into an audio presentation for the ''[[Lux Radio Theater]]''. Nelson Eddy, Susanna Foster and Edgar Barrier reprised their roles, but instead of Claude Rains, [[Basil Rathbone]] played Erique Claudin. This presentation was produced and hosted by [[Cecil B. DeMille]]. ==Score== [[File:Stage 28, or "Phantom of the Opera" Stage.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Stage 28, also known as ''The Phantom of the Opera'' Stage, was originally built for the [[The Phantom of the Opera (1925 film)|1925 film]], and reused in the 1943 version.]] [[Edward Ward (composer)|Edward Ward]] wrote the score. The film has many elements of a [[Musical films|musical]], with lengthy [[opera]] sequences, and has been criticized for being more musical than horrific. For the opera sequences, Ward adapted music from [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky|Tchaikovsky's]] [[Symphony No. 4 (Tchaikovsky)|Symphony No. 4]] as well as using themes by Chopin. He also composed an original theme, ''Lullaby of the Bells'', which was heard in the film as the Phantom's [[piano concerto]]. ==Reception== Contemporary reviews were mixed. [[Bosley Crowther]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' panned the film for being "watered down" from the original, calling the opening sequence "the only one in the film in which the potential excitement of the story is realized," while otherwise the "richness of décor and music is precisely what gets in the way of the tale."{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9904E3D91438E33BBC4D52DFB6678388659EDE |title=Movie Review - Phantom of the Opera |last=Crowther |first=Bosley |authorlink=Bosley Crowther |date=October 15, 1943 |website=[[The New York Times]] |publisher= |accessdate=February 21, 2016 }} ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' called it "a vivid, elaborate, and, within its original story limitations, an effective production geared for substantial grosses."{{cite journal |last= |first= |date=August 18, 1943 |title=Film Reviews |url= |journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |location=New York |publisher=Variety, Inc. |page= 10 |accessdate= }} ''[[Harrison's Reports]]'' called it "a good entertainment, the sort that will direct an appeal to all types of audiences."{{cite journal |last= |first= |date=August 21, 1943 |title='The Phantom of the Opera' with Nelson Eddy, Claude Rains and Susanna Foster |url= |journal=[[Harrison's Reports]] |location= |publisher= |page= 136 |accessdate= }} David Lardner's review in ''[[The New Yorker]]'' dismissed the film, calling it "by no means a sample of the march of progress in the film world. The old version had Lon Chaney, who scared you plenty, and the new one has Claude Rains, who somehow doesn't."{{cite journal |last=Lardner |first=David |date=October 16, 1943 |title=The Current Cinema |url= |journal=[[The New Yorker]] |location=New York |publisher=F-R Publishing Corp. |page= 53 |accessdate= }} [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gave this version of ''Phantom of the Opera'' an average score of 75%, based on 20 reviews from critics.[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1016241-phantom_of_the_opera/ Rotten Tomatoes: Phantom of the Opera (1943)] ==Cancelled sequel== Following the success of ''Phantom of the Opera'', Universal announced that a sequel would be made, titled ''[[The Climax]]''. Nelson Eddy and Susanna Foster were to return, along with Claude Rains as the Phantom, most likely meaning that his character survived the cave-in at the finale of the first film (indeed, in the final shot of the mask and violin atop the rubble, there is a sound of moving rock). The sequel, however, was later cancelled due to story troubles and problems concerning the availability of Claude Rains. ''[[The Climax]]'' was indeed released the year after ''Phantom of the Opera'', but it was not a continuation of the previous film and featured completely new characters. ==Awards== The film was nominated for four [[Academy Award]]s, winning in two categories:{{Cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1944 |title=The 16th Academy Awards (1944) Nominees and Winners |accessdate=2011-08-14|work=oscars.org}} * [[Academy Award for Best Production Design|Art Direction (Color)]] ([[John B. Goodman (art director)|John B. Goodman]], [[Alexander Golitzen]], [[Russell A. Gausman]] and [[Ira S. Webb]]) ('''Won''') * [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography|Cinematography (Color)]] (Hal Mohr and W. Howard Greene) ('''Won''') * [[Academy Award for Best Original Score|Music (Scoring of a Musical Picture)]] (Edward Ward) (''Nominated'') * [[Academy Award for Best Sound Mixing|Sound Recording]] ([[Bernard B. Brown]]) (''Nominated'') ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *{{Wikiquote-inline}} *{{AFI film|613|Phantom of the Opera}} *{{Amg movie|37950|Phantom of the Opera}} *{{IMDb title|0036261|Phantom of the Opera}} *[https://archive.org/download/Lux_Fills_and_Upgrades/Lux-430913-58m40s-406td-PhantomoftheOpera-NEddyBRathbone.mp3 '' Phantom of the Opera''] on [[Lux Radio Theater]]: September 13, 1943 {{Phantom of the Opera}} {{Universal Monsters}} {{Arthur Lubin}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1943 films]] [[Category:1940s horror films]] [[Category:1940s musical films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American film remakes]] [[Category:Horror film remakes]] [[Category:American horror films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about composers]] [[Category:Films about opera]] [[Category:Films based on horror novels]] [[Category:Films based on The Phantom of the Opera]] [[Category:Films directed by Arthur Lubin]] [[Category:Films set in a theatre]] [[Category:Films whose art director won the Best Art Direction Academy Award]] [[Category:Films whose cinematographer won the Best Cinematography Academy Award]] [[Category:American monster movies]] [[Category:Sound film remakes of silent films]] [[Category:Universal Classic Monsters films]] [[Category:Universal Pictures films]] [[Category:Films set in Paris]] [[Category:Films about violins and violinists]]

{{Infobox Game| subject_name='''Pie''' or, '''Pieman Pieman''' | image_link= | image_caption= | players=More than 3 | ages=3 and up | setup_time= 5 minutes or less | playing_time= No limit | complexity=Low | strategy=High | random_chance=Low | skills=[[Running]] | }} [[Image:Simple Simon 2 - WW Denslow - Project Gutenberg etext 18546.jpg|thumb|The Pieman by [[W.W. Denslow]]]]
'''Pie''' or, '''Pieman, Pieman''' is an outdoor [[game]] for more than three children. Its origin is unknown. A variant exists called Easter Eggs.
==Description== The game requires a seating area for the players (such as a flight of porch steps or a garden wall) which is designated the "Pie Shop" or "Bakery." Also required are a [[Goal]] distant from the seating area such as a tree, post or other object, and an expanse of lawn or field for a chase similar to the chase in the game of [[Tag (game)|Tag]].
One player is chosen Pieman, another Buyer, and the other players are Pies. The Buyer is sometimes designated Simple Simon following the [[Mother Goose]] rhyme:
:Simple Simon met a pieman :Going to the fair; :Says Simple Simon to the pieman, :"Let me taste your ware."
To begin the game, the Buyer is sent to the Goal where he cannot see or hear the other players. The Pieman then names each Pie with a common [[pie|pie filling]] such as Apple, Blueberry, Pumpkin, etc. When all the Pies have been named, the Pieman calls the Buyer to the Pie Shop.
The Buyer demands, "Pieman, Pieman, I would like a pie." The Pieman asks, "And what might that Pie be?" The Buyer then names a pie flavor such as Apple. If one of the Pies has been designated Apple, then he rushes from the Pie Shop to the Goal while the Buyer runs after him and attempts to [[Tag (game)|tag]] him. Both the Pie and the Buyer must touch the Goal before running back to the Pie Shop. If the Pie returns to the Pie Shop without being tagged, he resumes his seat, and is renamed for another round. The chase may be complicated with dodging about lawn furniture, flower beds, clotheslines of drying laundry, or other obstacles in the path to and from the Goal.
Before the Buyer leaves the Pie Shop in pursuit of the Pie, he is required to pay the Pieman the price he asks for the Pie (such as 10 dollars). Payment is accomplished by slapping the Pieman's outstretched, up-turned palm, and counting aloud the required number of "dollars." Paying the Pieman gives slower, or smaller Pies a "head-start" against the Buyer.
Should the Pie be "tagged" during his flight to the Goal, he becomes the Buyer, the Buyer becomes a Pie, and play resumes in a similar manner.
==Variants== A variation of the game for children who may have limited knowledge of pie flavors is Easter Eggs. Here, players are given colors (red, blue, green, purple，etc.) rather than pie fillings. The Pieman becomes The [[Easter Bunny]] and the seating area the Easter Basket. Another variant is called Red Devil, where one child is removed from the group, and the kids are assigned colors (pink,yellow,blue) the child then returns and says "Red Devil, Red Devil, may I borrow a crayon?" the group then asks "What color?" and like pie the color chosen must try to catch the asker before the asker takes that person's seat.
In another variant, the Buyer is known as the Witch. The Witch says to the Baker: "Do you have any pies today?" The Baker replies, "What kind do you want?" If the Witch names one of the Pies, he or she must chase the named Pie around a designated spot, such as a tree or a light post. If the Pie gets back to the Pie Shop safely, the game begins again. However, if the Pie is caught, he or she becomes the new Witch. The Witch now becomes a Pie and sits with the others on the Pie Shop shelf and the game continues.
== References == * Bluebird Flour, paper insert dated 1948 * http://www.gameskidsplay.net/games/chasing_games/pies.htm {{Refimprove|date=December 2008}}
{{Tag (game)}}
[[Category:Children's games]] [[Category:Tag variants]]

page.title: Pirate Baby's Cabana Battle Street Fight 2006

revision.comment: Adding another line, so that hopefully the warning gets seen /before/ the video is loaded.
revision.text:
[[File:PBCBSF2006.png|thumb|336px|The title screen, featuring the Pirate Baby.]] '''Pirate Baby's Cabana Battle Street Fight 2006''' is a 12-minute, black and white animated movie by [[Paul Robertson (animator)|Paul Laurence Robertson]], featuring music by [[Qua (musician)|Cornel Wilczek]],<ref>[http://www.popmatters.com/multimedia/reviews/p/pirate-babys-cabana-2006.shtml Pirate Baby's Cabana Battle Street Fight 2006], [[PopMatters]], March 15, 2006</ref> also known as Qua. It depicts a fictional [[Side-scrolling game|side-scroller video game]], "heavily influenced and inspired by [[anime]], cult 1980s games such as [[Double Dragon]], [[Bubble Bobble]] and [[R-Type]], and [[Culture of Australia|Australian popular culture]]"<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://2006festival.nextwave.org.au/objectlibrary/591 Press Release from the Next Wave Festival]</ref> in which two male characters must fight their way through a building full of [[zombies]], humans, giant [[Beetle#Development|grubs]] and [[octopuses]] to rescue a woman being held captive by the main antagonist, a pirate baby. The animation was created with [[Autodesk Animator]] and [[Adobe Flash]], and contains considerable gore and some nudity.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/tv/sundayarts/txt/Sunday2April2006.htm Paul Robertson Interview on [[Sunday Arts]]]</ref>
Sponsored by [[Melbourne]]'s [http://www.melbourne.vic.gov.au/info.cfm?top=75&pg=791 Living the Arts] program, it was first shown at the [[Next Wave Festival#2006_Next_Wave_Festival_.E2.80.93_Empire_Games|2006]] [[Next Wave Festival]]. It was released on the [[internet]] as a 113 MB [[MPEG-1|MPEG]] video on April 20, 2006.
==Synopsis== The fictional game begins with an introductory title sequence. There are five play levels, each with a [[Boss (video games)|boss]] at the end. The two heroes each have a preferred fighting style; one primarily uses a [[baseball bat]], though he also uses [[Uzi]]s at one point, and the other utilizes a variety of kicks. Numerous [[Fighting game#Special attacks|special attack]]s are used, including three which are specifically named: * ''[[Datsun 180b]] [[Monster Truck]]'' * ''The Ghosts of a Billion Dead Mosquitos'' * ''[[The Big Lebowski|You are Entering a World of Pain]]''
It ends with credits and stills depicting events after the pirate baby is defeated.
==Legacy== The video was generally well-received, but considered inappropriate for children due to intense violence and some nudity. Robertson later made a second movie, ''Kings of Power 4 Billion%'', also featuring music by Wilczek. Robertson later became involved in the art direction for the videogame, ''[[Scott Pilgrim vs. the World: The Game]]'', based on the ''[[Scott Pilgrim]]'' series of graphic novels, which was released on August 10, 2010. He was also involved in the creation of the official music video of Architecture in Helsinki's 'Do The Whirlwind'.
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://probertson.livejournal.com/ Paul Robertson's Journal] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xyvu5QTbPkk The animation on YouTube] * [http://www.quamusic.com/ Music composer Cornel Wilczek's site]
[[Category:Viral videos]] [[Category:Animated short films]] [[Category:Web animation]] [[Category:Cinema of Australia]] [[Category:Australian comedy]] [[Category:Fictional games]]
{{short-animation-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{ infobox | above = Ultimate Magic | image1 = [[File:UMlogo.gif|180px]] | caption1 = Ultimate Magic Logo | header1 = Details | label2 = Launched: | data2 = September 1, 2008 | label3 = Venue: | data3 = The Arena @ '''[[Clarke Quay]]''' | label4 = Producer: | data4 = '''[http://www.conceptmagic.biz Concept: Magic]''' | label5 = Stars: | data5 = '''[[J C Sum]]''' & '''[[Magic Babe Ning|'Magic Babe' Ning]]''' | label6 = Website: | data6 = '''http://www.ultimatemagic.sg''' }}
'''Ultimate Magic''' is [[Singapore]]’s first permanent illusion show at The Arena @ [[Clarke Quay]].<ref name=bloodsugarsexmagic>"Blood Sugar Sex Magic", FiRST, August issue</ref><ref name=hotstuff>Hot Stuff Magazine Singapore: Model Profile, September 2008, Issue 67</ref><ref name=bagpage>"The Bag Page", The Straits Times Urban, 12 September 2008</ref><ref name=currentevents>"The Sum of All Illusions" (Cover Story), Current Events Issue 7.1, September 2008</ref> The show was Singapore’s only magic attraction<ref name=webwire3>[http://www.webwire.com/ViewPressRel.asp?aId=94841 “Singapore Illusionist & Sexy Female Magician Make a Magical Appearance for Asia Uncut Talk Show on Star World”], retrieved 19 May 09</ref> and it was officially endorsed as a live attraction by the [[Singapore Tourism Board]].<ref name=STB>[http://www.visitsingapore.com/publish/stbportal/en/home/what_to_do/nightlife_in_singapore/nightspot/singapore_river/clarke_quay.1.2.2.html “What to do”], Uniquely Singapore, retrieved 20 May 2009</ref>
Produced and managed by Concept: Magic, Singapore’s only full service magic production house,<ref name="currentevents"/><ref name=artjam>"It is Not a Trick, Just Magic" (Cover Story), Art Jam, Jan - Mar 2009 issue</ref> the show opened in September 2008<ref name=fhmjcsum>"Quote/ Unquote: The Illusionist", FHM Singapore, August 2008 issue</ref> and started its third season, '''''Ultimate Magic: The Revolution''''' on 2 May 2009, ending in August 2009.
[[File:UltimateMagic Season II.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Ultimate Magic Season II, 2009]]
==Synopsis== Ultimate Magic starred Singapore professional magic duo, [[J C Sum]] & [[Magic Babe Ning|'Magic Babe' Ning]]. The show is a partnership between the co-stars, Sum and Ning.<ref name=jobdb>[http://www.jobsdb.com.sg/Singapore/campus/spotlight_cooljobs_magician.htm "Cool Jobs - Magician"], JobsDB.com, 24 September 2008</ref><ref name=asiauncut>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eaDI1NU3U8U “Asia Uncut Episode 10, Part 3 of 6 Magic Babe Ning & JC Sum”], Starworld, Air Date: 17 May 2009</ref> The show is described as “Urban Illusions in the City” and is a magical personification of the characteristics of Singapore city.<ref name="currentevents"/>
==Stars== Sum and Ning's partnership as a professional magic duo has been acknowledged as “very groundbreaking and refreshing”<ref name="jobdb"/> and they were said to represent “the new faces of an age-old art form”.<ref name=cnaprimetime>"Primetime Morning Interview”, Channel News Asia, 19 January 2009</ref> They are best known for a teleportation feat across [[Singapore River]] where three volunteers were teleported across Singapore River in just 2.5 seconds.<ref name=hotstuff2>[http://www.hotstuffmag.net/modelsDetail.php?ID=067MN Hot Stuff Magazine Singapore] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080914002045/http://www.hotstuffmag.net/modelsDetail.php?ID=067MN |date=2008-09-14 }}, Cover September 2008 Issue 67</ref><ref name = F1>[http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/355938/1/.html Lifestyle activities planned for Singapore's first F1 race], Channel News Asia, 23 June 2008</ref><ref name = wobaoimpossible>"魔术宝贝2.5秒让你消失",WOBAO, 8 August 2008</ref><ref name = trickwithtreats>"Trick with Treats", The Straits Times LIFE!, 12 September 2008</ref><ref name = lhwbTIJ>“神奇魔术表演千名观众惊叹”, Lianhe Wanbao, 25 September 2008</ref><ref name = lhzbTIJ>[http://zaobao.com/sp/sp080925_529.shtml "新加坡河大型幻术表演 三人在数千人眼皮下消失"], Lianhe Zaobao, 25 September 2008</ref><ref name = xinTIJ>[http://www.xin.sg/article.php?article=23894 "幻术师瞬间传送真人 穿新加坡河畔"], xin.sg, 24 September 2008</ref><ref name=ch8TIJ>[http://video2.channelnewsasia.com/cnavideos/chineseplayer.asp?skin=Player1.swf&player=chineseplayer.swf&filename=xin_092408_magicshow.flv Channel 8 News] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081003172302/http://video2.channelnewsasia.com/cnavideos/chineseplayer.asp?skin=Player1.swf&player=chineseplayer.swf&filename=xin_092408_magicshow.flv |date=2008-10-03 }}, 24 September 2008 (VIDEO)</ref><ref name = ch5TIJ>Channel 5 News, 24 September 2008</ref><ref name = cnaTIJ2>"Singapore Tonight, Channel NewsAsia, 24 September 2008</ref>
==Illusions in the show== Original illusions in the show (all seasons) include:<ref name="bloodsugarsexmagic"/><ref name=kozine2>”Magic Day 2009”, Kozine, April 2009</ref> *J C's cross country teleportation *Crystal Metamorphosis – J C & Ning's instant double teleportation *Revollusion – An illusion with an 8-ft industrial fan *Dreamscape: The Realm of Sandman *Extreme Burn – An escape from a flaming spear
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.ultimatemagic.sg Ultimate Magic]
;Related videos *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H_SRI6phvfc Singapore's first permanent illusion show "Ultimate Magic" video trailer] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MUTQZ3TAPFk Singapore Magic tourist attraction and first daily illusion show "Ultimate Magic: The Revolution"] *[http://multimedia.asiaone.com/Multimedia/Story/Ultimate%2BMagic.html “Ultimate Magic” - AsiaOne Video] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qe4uQxrkG_w Revollusion fan illusion by 'Magic Babe' Ning and J C Sum, Asia's most lethal combination in magic - Youtube Video] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vUrry-kH9q8 'Magic Babe' Ning and J C Sum Crystal Metamorphosis - see-through substitution trunk illusion - Youtube video]
{{Magic and Illusion}}

'''''Vamos vamos Argentina''''' is a very popular [[chant]] in [[Argentina]], used by supporters in sports events, mainly in [[football (soccer)]] matches of the [[Argentina national football team|national team]] and related celebrations. ==Lyrics== In Spanish: {{Quote| Vamos, vamos Argentina,
vamos, vamos a ganar,
que esta barra ''quilombera'',
no te deja, no te deja de alentar. }} English translation: {{Quote| Let's go, let's go Argentina,
We're going, we're going to win,
for these raucous supporters,
won't stop, won't stop cheering you.}} The adjective ''quilombera'' used in the third line is a mildly obscene term. In the [[lunfardo]] argot, ''[[quilombo]]'' means [[brothel]]; the word is used by Argentines (when profanity is tolerated) to mean "bedlam" or "mess". In this case, ''quilombera'' is used to describe the fact that football fans make a lot of noise and usually a mess of throwing [[confetti]] when goals are scored. On recordings, or when profanity is not tolerated, ''quilombera'' is replaced by ''bullanguera'' ("rackety"). This chant unites all of Argentina's supporters regardless of their club allegiance. It had its first heyday during the [[1978 World Cup]], played in Argentina, and is often the first song attempted by Argentine expatriates when the national team visits a foreign country. Usage has spread to [[Argentina national basketball team|basketball]] and [[volleyball]] teams, but not to the [[Los Pumas]] rugby union team (normally they use ''Yo te daré, te daré una cosa'' -''I will give you/I will give you a thing''-). The other most popular chant among Argentine fans is ''Es un sentimiento ... no puedo parar'' ( {{lang-en|It's a feeling ... I can't stop}} [''cheering''])[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cGQ8g8r2e1o video in Germany WC] == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vamos Vamos Argentina}} [[Category:Football songs and chants]] [[Category:Argentina national football team]] [[Category:National sports teams of Argentina| ]] [[Category:Argentine music]] [[Category:Spanish-language songs]] [[Category:Year of song missing]] [[Category:Songs about Argentina]]

{{Multiple issues| {{POV|date=July 2017}} {{advert|date=July 2017}} {{Orphan|date=May 2014}} }} {{Infobox company |name = Viamedia |logo = Viamedia_Company_Logo_-_2016.jpg |type = Corporation |genre = |foundation = 2001 |founder = Jeff Carter
Todd Donnelly |location_city = [[New York, New York]]
[[Lexington, Kentucky]],
[[Salt Lake City, Utah]] |location_country = |location = |origins = |key_people = Mark Lieberman, President & CEO{{cite web|title=Mark Lieberman|url=http://www.cynopsis.com/mark-lieberman/|publisher=Cynopsis|accessdate=9 August 2016}}
Chris Black, Chief Financial Officer{{cite web|title=Company Overview of Viamedia, Inc.|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/people.asp?privcapId=30763327|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=9 August 2016}}
Randy Lykes, Chief Technology Officer{{cite web|last1=Reynolds|first1=Mike|title=Next TV: 'TV Everywhere' Needs More Uniformity|url=http://www.multichannel.com/news/content/next-tv-tv-everywhere-needs-more-uniformity/359045|publisher=Multichannel News|accessdate=9 August 2016}}
Becky Jones, Chief Marketing & People Officer{{cite web|last1=Young|first1=Alicia|title=Becky Jones Appointed Chief Marketing & People Officer|url=http://www.madmarketer.com/topics/news/articles/425082-becky-jones-appointed-chief-marketing-people-officer.htm|publisher=Mad Marketer|accessdate=29 November 2016}}
David Solomon, Chief Revenue Officer{{cite web|last1=Corr|first1=Amy|title=Viamedia; David Solomon|url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/279118/viamedia-david-solomon.html?edition=|publisher=MediaPost|accessdate=9 August 2016}}
Rick Tarvin, EVP of Sales{{cite web|last1=Corr|first1=Amy|title=Viamedia; Rick Tarvin|url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/280541/viamedia-rick-tarvin.html|publisher=MediaPost|accessdate=9 August 2016}}
Billy Stewart, VP of Digital Sales & Ops
Derek Mattsson, President of Placemedia{{cite web|title=Derek Mattsson|url=http://videosummit2016.videonuze.com/author/view/371|publisher=VideoNuze|accessdate=9 August 2016}} |area_served = |industry = Cable television |products = Advertising |services = |revenue = |operating_income = |net_income = |num_employees = 350 |parent = |divisions = |subsid = |owner = |caption = |homepage = [http://www.viamediatv.com ViamediaTV.com] |dissolved = |footnotes = }} '''Viamedia''' is the largest independent [[cable television|cable]] TV ad management company for local, regional and national advertising, programmatic and ad tech [[solution]]s{{what|date=October 2018}} in the United States.{{cite web|last1=Kuhl|first1=Craig|title=Big Names Head 50th Class of Cable TV Pioneers|url=http://www.multichannel.com/big-names-head-50th-class-cable-tv-pioneers/404923|publisher=Multichannel News|accessdate=9 August 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Swedlow|first1=Tracy|title=Viamedia-placemedia|url=http://thetvoftomorrowshow.com/viamedia-placemedia|publisher=TV of Tomorrow|accessdate=9 August 2016}}[http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=30763327 "Company Overview of Viamedia, Inc."] ''Bloomberg Businessweek''. Retrieved 2014-1-26. The company currently has more than 12,000 active and prospective advertisers nationwide. With headquarters in [[New York City]] and [[Lexington, Kentucky]], Viamedia sells advertising on behalf of U.S. cable and telecommunications service providers, utility companies and municipalities. The company manages the sales, operational and technical back room functions for 60 MVPDs (aka cable companies) across 71 DMAs in over 30 states, delivering ads into nearly one million spots daily.{{cite web|title=Mark Lieberman|url=http://www.cablefaxmultiscreensummit.com/ddg-speaker/mark-lieberman/|publisher=Cablefax|accessdate=9 August 2016}} Viamedia has more than 350 employees nationwide.{{cite web|title=Becky Jones|url=http://www.cablefax.com/cablefax_profile/becky-jones-4|publisher=Cablefax|accessdate=9 August 2016}} Viamedia also owns Placemedia, a fully automated programmatic planning and buying [[solution]] for linear television.{{cite web|title=Broadway Systems Partners with Placemedia|url=https://www.thebroadcastbridge.com/content/entry/2259/broadway-systems-partners-with-placemedia|publisher=The Broadcast Bridge|accessdate=9 August 2016}} ==History== Viamedia was founded in 2001 by Jeff Carter and Todd Donnelly.[http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/105134-Jeff_Carter_Co_founder_and_President_ViaMedia.php Jeff Carter Co-founder and President ViaMedia"] ''Broadcasting & Cable''. Retrieved 2014-1-26. In January 2011, Viamedia announced that it has partnered with Lake Capital, a private equity firm that invests exclusively in service-based companies.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/13/idUS11898+13-Jan-2011+BW20110113 "Viamedia and Lake Capital Partner to Grow Local Advertising Services Provider"] ''Reuters''. Retrieved 2014-1-26. In 2014, Mark Lieberman was hired as President and CEO, having previously served as co-founder and CEO of TRA, a television and Big Data analytics, software and research technology firm acquired by TiVo.[http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/216842/real-time-with-mark-lieberman-viamedias-new-ceo.html "Real-Time With Mark Lieberman, Viamedia's New CEO, On Data-Driven TV Ads"] ''MediaPost''. Retrieved 2014-5-20. Since then, the company has earned Multichannel News’ Innovator Award for technological developments in audience targeting and reporting, has been named a Top Operator by Cablefax back-to-back years and received the Affiliate and Partnership Marketing award at the 2014 FAXIE Awards for its "Your Partner for Ad Sales" campaign. ==Placemedia== A wholly owned subsidiary of Viamedia, Placemedia is a fully automated supply-side programmatic planning and buying [[solution]] for linear television. The company combines multiple consumer databases, viewing behavior from millions of household set-top boxes, and a proprietary technology platform that automatically places media buys to reach highly targeted audiences.{{cite web|last1=Ellis|first1=Leslie|title=INTX 2016: Lots Going On in Advanced Advertising, But Still Fragmented|url=http://www.multichannel.com/news/cable-tv-conventions/intx-2016-lots-going-advanced-advertising-still-fragmented/405036|publisher=Multichannel News|accessdate=17 August 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Minichini|first1=Steve|title=MBPT Spotlight: What Does Programmatic Mean for TV: A Snapshot of Options|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/news/currency/mbpt-spotlight-what-does-programmatic-mean-tv-snapshot-options/136075|publisher=Broadcasting & Cable|accessdate=17 August 2016}} The company currently represents more than 30 billion impressions monthly in nearly 100M TV households across 210 DMAs. Placemedia’s platform connects demand side players (agencies and advertisers) with aggregated television ad inventory from Placemedia’s supply side partners MVPDs and cable TV networks.{{cite web|last1=Loechner|first1=Tyler|title=Placemedia Rolls Out 'Programmatic Upfront' For TV|url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/249414/placemedia-rolls-out-programmatic-upfront-for-tv.html|publisher=MediaPost|accessdate=17 August 2016}} Using its application program interface (API), Placemedia’s programmatic platform has been directly integrated into Demand Side Platform (DSP) partners’ preexisting systems.{{cite web|last1=Loechner|first1=Tyler|title=TubeMogul Plugs Into Placemedia's Programmatic TV Platform|url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/254262/tubemogul-plugs-into-placemedias-programmatic-tv.html|publisher=MediaPost|accessdate=17 August 2016}} Placemedia is headquartered in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]].{{cite web|title=Directory - Placemedia, Inc.|url=http://www.utahtech.org/Advertising/placemedia,-Inc-4235|publisher=Utah Technology Council|accessdate=24 August 2016}} ==Services== Viamedia provides media [[solution]]s{{what|date=October 2018}} for more than 12,000 local, regional and national advertisers, including inserting advertising onto cable networks such as [[ESPN]], [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT]], [[FOX News]], Lifetime, HGTV, A&E, Hallmark Channel and others.{{cite web|title=Viamedia|url=http://web.naperville.net/Media/Viamedia-19496|publisher=Naperville Area Chamber of Commerce|accessdate=11 August 2016}} In addition, the company has a relationship with National Cable Communications, a spot cable advertising representation firm, to facilitate national sales by enabling advertisers to reach all households within a given market through multiple operators.[http://newscenter2.verizon.com/press-releases/verizon/2009/verizon-fios-tv-and-viamedia.html "Verizon FiOS TV and Viamedia Extend Advertising Representation Agreement"] Verizon. Retrieved 2014-1-26. The company also offers a true multi-screen [[solution]]{{what|date=October 2018}} for advertisers across the US.{{cite web|title=Viamedia|url=http://chambermaster.wakeforestchamber.org/list/member/viamedia-raleigh-8710|publisher=Wake Forest Area Chamber of Commerce|accessdate=11 August 2016}} This includes pre-roll video, SEM and mobile.{{cite web|last1=Tso|first1=Richard|title=EXCLUSIVE: Viamedia To Launch Programmatic TV Ad Exchange At Advertising Week|url=http://www.adotas.com/2013/09/exclusive-viamedia-to-launch-programmatic-tv-ad-exchange-at-advertising-week/|publisher=Adotas|accessdate=11 August 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Dickson|first1=Dan|title=In 12 years, Lexington-Based Viamedia has Grown to 57 Markets and 465 Employees|url=http://bizlex.com/2013/07/in-12-years-lexington-based-viamedia-has-grown-to-57-markets-and-465-employees/|publisher=Business Lexington|accessdate=11 August 2016}} ==Operations== Viamedia technically inserts, delivers and verifies nearly one million 15 and 30-second television spots each day.{{cite web|last1=Kuperberg|first1=Jonathan|title=Fates Roundup, July 28, 2015|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/blog/fates-and-fortunes/fates-roundup-july-28-2015/142887|publisher=Broadcasting & Cable|accessdate=17 August 2016}} Viamedia also provides advertising technical sales functions including research, traffic and billing, video encoding, and technical assistance and monitoring.{{cite web|last1=BBC Staff Report|title=Fiber-To-The-Home Top 100|url=http://www.bbpmag.com/2014mags/July/BBC_Jul14_Top100.pdf|publisher=Broadband Communities Magazine|accessdate=17 August 2016}} ==Awards and recognition== In 2016, Viamedia CEO, Mark Lieberman, was inducted as a Cable Center Cable Pioneer.{{cite web|title=Current Pioneers|url=http://cablecenter.org/current-pioneers.html|publisher=The Cable Center|accessdate=24 August 2016}} Viamedia executives have been named to the Cablefax Top 100;{{cite web|title=The 100|url=http://accessintelligence.imirus.com/Mpowered/book/vcabfax16/i2/p62|publisher=Cablefax|accessdate=24 August 2016}} Cablefax Most Powerful Women in Cable;{{cite web|last1=Entertainment Close-up|title=Viamedia Executives Rank on Cablefax: The Magazine's 'Most Powerful Women in Cable'|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-389832475.html|publisher=HighBeam Research|accessdate=24 August 2016}} Cynopsis Top Women in Digital;{{cite web|title=2016 Honorees|url=http://www.cynopsis.com/event/top-women-in-digital-event/|publisher=Cynopsis|accessdate=24 August 2016}} Cablefax Most Powerful Women in Technology; and Multichannel News’ "40 Under 40" list.{{cite web|last1=Gibbons|first1=Kent|title=40 Under 40 Class of 2015|url=http://www.multichannel.com/news/people/40-under-40/392487|publisher=Multichannel News|accessdate=24 August 2016}} Viamedia received the Affiliate and Partnership Marketing award at the 2014 FAXIE Awards in NYC for its "Your Partner for Ad Sales" campaign.{{cite web|title=The FAXIES Awards|url=http://www.cablefax.com/eventsawardswebinars/the-faxies|publisher=Cablefax|accessdate=24 August 2016}} Viamedia’s programmatic platform, Placemedia, was awarded the 2014 Innovator Award by Multichannel News.{{cite web|last1=MCN Staff|title='MCN’ Announces Innovator Award Winners|url=http://www.multichannel.com/news/products/mcn-announces-innovator-award-winners/384289|publisher=Multichannel News|accessdate=24 August 2016}} Viamedia was named a Top Operator by Cablefax back-to-back in 2013 and 2014.{{cite web|title=The Top Operators of 2013|url=http://www.cablefax.com/the-lists/top-ops-2013|publisher=Cablefax|accessdate=24 August 2016}}{{cite web|title=The Top Operators of 2014|url=http://www.cablefax.com/the-lists/top-ops-2014|publisher=Cablefax|accessdate=24 August 2016}} In 2014, Viamedia was named one of the Top 100 Companies in Fiber to the Home Industry by Broadband Communities. == References == {{Reflist|3}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Viamedia}} [[Category:Companies established in 2001]] [[Category:Television advertising]]

revision.text:
{{Expand Japanese|XBLAZE CODE:EMBRYO|date=July 2014|topic=vg}} {{Infobox video game |title = Xblaze Code: Embryo |image = xblazecodeembryo.png |image_size = 250px |caption = Japanese PlayStation 3 box art |developer = [[Arc System Works]] |publisher = {{vgrelease|JP|[[Arc System Works]]|NA|[[Aksys Games]]|EU|[[Funbox Media]]}} |composer = Kikuo |series = ''[[BlazBlue]]'' |released = '''PlayStation 3, PlayStation Vita'''{{vgrelease|JP|July 23, 2013|NA|June 24, 2014|EU|September 18, 2015}}'''Microsoft Windows'''
{{Video game release|WW|March 1, 2016}} |genre = [[Visual novel]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = [[PlayStation 3]], [[PlayStation Vita]], [[Microsoft Windows]] }} {{nihongo|'''XBlaze Code: Embryo'''|エクスブレイズ コード：エンブリオ|EkusuBureizu Kōdo: Enburio}} is a [[prequel]] [[visual novel]] of the [[fighting game]] series ''[[BlazBlue]]'' by [[Arc System Works]]. It was released in [[Japan]] for the [[PlayStation 3]] and [[PlayStation Vita]] on July 23, 2013 and [[North America]] on June 24, 2014 by [[Aksys Games]].2013-07-05, [http://www.famitsu.com/news/201307/05036040.html 『エクスブレイズ コード：エンブリオ』森Pインタビュー！ 物語の舞台は『ブレイブルー』の150年前！？], [[Famitsu]] The [[Microsoft Windows]]'s version was released worldwide on March 1, 2016. A sequel titled ''[[XBlaze Lost: Memories]]'' has been released for the PS3 and Vita in 2015 and on Windows in 2016. ==Synopsis== The protagonist, Touya Kagari, is a resident of Shin Yokozaki City and a sophomore at the prestigious Hakuou North Academy. An earnest and responsible young man, Touya appears to be no more than your average high school student. While returning from his part-time job, he heard a mysterious sound coming from the depths of the Restricted Ward, an area off-limits to unauthorized personnel due to a horrible disaster that happened there ten years ago. His curiosity having gotten the best of him, Touya ventured ever deeper into the ruins of the ward, eventually coming across a man who appeared to be gravely injured. Concerned, Touya rushed to his side, asking if he was okay and if he needed any help. But as Touya approached, the man suddenly stood up and attacked, screaming, “You’re an enemy!” And in the midst of invisible ringing bells, psychotic strangers, exploding walls of flame, and almost certain death, a small, cute girl with an enormous sword came charging in. And despite her frilly, fragile appearance, her battle prowess was beyond reason or doubt. The name of Touya’s savior was Es, a soldier belonging to the Mitsurugi Agency. Seithr, Drives, Unions, and secretive organizations. Yanked from the comfort of his everyday life, Touya was forced head-long into a world where the threat of death was everywhere and even allies could be his downfall. The wheel of fate has begun to turn. And the story of the Azure, and that of Touya Kagari and the mysterious girl Es, began.{{cite web|accessdate=February 28, 2015|url=http://aksysgames.com/xblaze/story/|title=Story}} ===Main Characters=== *'''Touya Kagari''', in addition to being naturally curious, he also is incredibly kind and compassionate. Despite his calm demeanor, he will charge head long into any fights he sees in order to stop them. Currently lives with the Himezuru family and works part-time at the curry restaurant “Maha Raja”.{{cite web|accessdate=February 28, 2015|url=http://aksysgames.com/xblaze/touya/|title=Touya}} *'''Hinata Himezuru''', the younger sister of the Himezuru family, of which Touya is unofficially a member. Incredibly friendly and cheerful, she always looks like she’s enjoying life. She is the de facto head of the household as her older sister Yuki, who is a doctor, is always at work. However, she truly enjoys housework, especially cooking.{{cite web|accessdate=February 28, 2015|url=http://aksysgames.com/xblaze/hinata/|title=Hinata}} *'''Es''', an anti-ability warrior (aka Sleipnir) attached to the Mitsurugi Agency. Outside of combat operations, she is shockingly naive and ignorant about the world around her. She rarely speaks or shows her emotions. In addition to her fighting prowess, she can also detect Discover Calls.{{cite web|accessdate=February 28, 2015|url=http://aksysgames.com/xblaze/es/|title=ES}} *'''Kuon Glamred Stroheim''', an apprentice at the Academy located on the isle of Ishana. A daughter of the powerful Stroheim family, she has no tolerance for malfeasance and her tendency to white knight frequently gets her in trouble. Her temper is legendary, earning her the nickname “Fire Empress Stroheim”. Due to her potential strength, most believe she will be the first in a long while to earn the right to become a Ten Sage.{{cite web|accessdate=February 28, 2015|url=http://aksysgames.com/xblaze/kuon/|title=Kuon}} *'''Mei Amanohokosaka''', grudgingly works with the Mitsurugi Agency. The scion of the Amanohokosaka clan, she has been hunting Unions since she was a child. As a result, she is far more mature than her peers and often has problems relating to them. She practices a unique form of magic which she uses primarily to obtain information, though she will occasionally use her powers in combat.{{cite web|accessdate=February 28, 2015|url=http://aksysgames.com/xblaze/mei/|title=Mei}} ==Reception== {{expand section|date=July 2015}} {{Video game reviews | GR = (PSV) 55%{{cite web|accessdate=February 28, 2015|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/vita/712277-xblaze-code-embryo/index.html|title=XBLAZE Code: Embryo for PlayStation Vita|publisher=GameRankings}} | MC = (PSV) 43/100{{cite web|accessdate=February 28, 2015|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-vita/xblaze-code-embryo|title=XBLAZE Code: Embryo for PlayStation Vita Reviews|publisher=Metacritic}} | Fam = 30/40{{cite web|url=http://gematsu.com/2013/07/famitsu-review-scores-issue-1280|title=Famitsu Review Scores: Issue 1280|publisher=Gematsu|author=Sal Romano|date=July 16, 2013|accessdate=February 28, 2015}} | rev1 = ''[[NeoGAF|Gaming Age]]'' | rev1Score = B{{cite web|url=http://www.gaming-age.com/2014/07/xblaze-code-embryo-review-ps-vita-ps3/|title=XBlaze Code: Embryo review for PS Vita, PS3|publisher=Gaming Age|author=Matthew Pollesel|date=July 3, 2014|accessdate=February 28, 2015}} | rev2 = ''[[Pocket Gamer]]'' | rev2Score = 6/10{{cite web|url=http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/PS+Vita/XBlaze+Code%3A+Embryo/review.asp?c=60424|title=XBlaze Code: Embryo review - PlayStation Vita reviews|publisher=Pocket Gamer|author=Tom Farndon|date=July 9, 2014|accessdate=February 28, 2015}} | rev3 = ''[[USGamer]]'' | rev3Score = 0.5/5{{cite web|url=http://www.usgamer.net/articles/xblaze-code-embryo-review-vita|title=XBlaze Code: Embryo PS Vita Review: A Compelling Argument for Illiteracy|publisher=USgamer|author=Bob Mackey|date=July 3, 2014|accessdate=February 28, 2015}} }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website | http://aksysgames.com/xblaze/}} {{BlazBlue Series}} {{Arc System Works}} [[Category:2013 video games]] [[Category:Arc System Works games]] [[Category:BlazBlue]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:PlayStation Vita games]] [[Category:Video game prequels]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Visual novels]] [[Category:Windows games]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=February 2012}} {{coord|56|49|33|N|60|36|19|E|display=title}} [[File:Yekaterinburg Circus.jpg|240px|thumb|The circus with the unfinished TV tower behind.]] '''Yekaterinburg Circus''' is a circus building for 2600 spectators in [[Yekaterinburg]]. Yeaterinburg circus has a lattice steel dome with a distinctive shape, which makes one of the [[Yekaterinburg]]'s landmarks. The circus was built in 1980 on the right bank of [[Iset river]].
The circus building is situated in the central part of the city, at crossing of 8 Marta street and Kuybysheva street next to [[Geologicheskaya]] metro station.
==External links== *[http://old.ekburg.ru/admeng/otd/10053_0_0_0/ The Ekaterinburg State Circus by V.I. Filatov]
[[Category:Circuses]] [[Category:Event venues established in 1980]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Yekaterinburg]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Sverdlovsk Oblast]]
